thread.title: Jo Moir: Prime Minister's effort to learn Te Reo well received at Ratana
thread.title_full: Jo Moir: Prime Minister's effort to learn Te Reo well received at Ratana

author: Jo Moir
title: Jo Moir: Prime Minister's effort to learn Te Reo well received at Ratana
text:
Murray Wilson/ Fairfax NZ. 
Gareth Morgan, Opportunities Party leader, used his speech at Ratana to attack NZ First leader Winston Peters. 
Little and Greens co-leader James Shaw did put in their own decent effort - even philanthropist Gareth Morgan of the newly formed Opportunities Party gave it a brief crack - although asking for someone to sing his waiata for him at the end was a tad awkward until Labour MP Meka Whaitiri took one for the team and leaped up to help. 
Ratana - the first big Maori event on the political calendar - is often held up as a taster of what's to come at Waitangi. 
But with English not attending this year - former leader John Key didn't go last year and the biggest headline was Steven Joyce getting hit in the head by a dildo - it's unlikely there will be any where near the controversy that's surrounded the event in years gone by. Ad Feedback 
If anything Ratana has given the country a taste of the political brawls leading into the election and there's two clear competitions on that front: Winston Peters v Gareth Morgan and Labour v the Maori Party. 
The claws are out and the war of words exchanged between Maori Party co-leader Te Ururoa Flavell and Labour leader Andrew Little over the last two days, in particular, suggest the Maori seats could be anyone's. 
After all, Little wouldn't be so fired up by the Maori Party's attacks if he was confident his own MPs could retain their six seats. - Stuff
